VLIB Function Reference

Binary Skeletonization (Thinning)

Introduction and Use Cases

Binary skeletonization is also known as thinning. It is used to transform binary images down to a single pixel wide representation. The term skeletonization comes from the fact that the resultant image appears like the skeleton of the original image.

Specification

Function

This function computes Binary Skeletonization (Thinning) using multiple iterations of hit-or-miss transform on 90 degree rotated versions of the given structural elements. It takes an array of programmable 3x3 masks (mask[][]) and their respective "don't care" masks (mask_d[][]). The number of masks that the mask[][] parameter points to is given by the num_st parameter.

In binary skeletonization, a single 3x3 mask is represented by 1's (foreground), 0's (background), and X's (don't cares). This API uses two parameters to specify this information: mask[][] and mask_d[][]. The 1's and 0's locations in the mask are specified using the mask[][] parameter, and the X's (don't care) locations are specified by using 1 values in the mask_d[][] paramter, as shown below. 

        Example:
               1 0 1             1 0 1              0 0 0
         For:  X 1 X  :  mask =  0 1 0    mask_d =  1 0 1
               X 0 X             0 0 0              1 0 1

This function internally calls the VLIB_hitmiss_bin function for each of the 4 orientations for each structuring element.

Inputs


    Parameter     Description
    ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    in_data[]     Input image pointer                                                   (32-bit packed binary)
    out_data[]    Output image pointer                                                  (32-bit packed binary)
    scratch[]     Scratch buffer                                                               (UQ8.0)
    mask[][]      Pointer to array of 3x3 structural element masks                             (UQ8.0)
    mask_d[][]    Pointer to array of 3x3 "don't care" masks                                   (UQ8.0)
    width         Width of the image (in terms of bits, since it is packed)                    (UQ16.0)
    height        Height of the image                                                          (UQ16.0)
    num_st        Number of 3x3 structural elements in mask array, must be > 0.                (UQ8.0)
    iters         As an input, this is the maximum number of iterations to run the algorithm.
                  A value of 0 is the same as setting it to 255.  This value will return the
                  actual number of iterations run.                                            (UQ8.0)

APIS

  • VLIB_binarySkeleton
  • VLIB_hitmiss_bin
